author: third_watch
title: Firefighters hike up Table Mountain to extinguish fire above Kirstenbosch
summary: A nearly inaccessible fire on the upper slopes of Table Mountain above Kirstenbosch, has forced firefighters to abandon their fire trucks and hike up the mountain instead. City of Cape Town Fire and Rescue spokesperson Theo Layne said that the large vegetation fire, which was reported on Monday afternoon, had not yet been contained. "Because of the inaccessibility of the fire and the wind conditions, we are not able to determine how long it will take to contain it," Layne said. "Forty-five firefighters, with the assistance of Table Mountain National Parks officials, and a helicopter have been deployed."

author: ipostwhaticareabout
title: 2 firefighters in hurt in falls battling brush fire
summary: ALTOONA, Pa. (AP) — Two firefighters were hurt in falls while battling a brush fire in central Pennsylvania, and two others were treated for dehydration and heat exhaustion. The Altoona Mirror reports that about 50 volunteer firefighters responded to the scene Saturday after a transformer malfunction ignited a fire in a wooded area in Logan Township near Altoona. The state forestry department also responded, arranging for a helicopter to help douse the flames. District Chief Tony Tanzi says the steep ground and gusty wind complicated the battle for firefighters. Firefighters were on scene for more than six hours.

author: nanook
title: Flames Snake Across Thousands of Acres of Oklahoma Prairie Land

author: DeltaBravo
title: Horses evacuated during wildfire return to San Diego stables
summary: SAN DIEGO (AP) — Hundreds of thoroughbred horses evacuated during a wildfire late last year are heading back to their home at the San Luis Rey Training Center near San Diego, according to a report. Forty-six horses were killed when the Lilac Fire on Dec. 7 raced across rolling hills near Fallbrook, known for barns and avocado groves. More than 400 surviving thoroughbreds are being brought back to new, temporary stables or refurbished older ones that withstood the blaze, the Los Angeles Times reported Friday. The horses had been stabled about 35 miles (56 kilometers) to the south at Del Mar racetrack. All the horses should be back at the training center by the end of the weekend. Accompanying

author: third_watch
title: Small brush fire near Greek Theatre prompts evacuation at Griffith Observatory

author: ipostwhaticareabout
title: Colorado's summer wildfire season could be the worst since 2012 and 2013, state officials say
summary: Conditions are setting up what could be the worst summer wildfire season in Colorado since the one-two punch of 2012 and 2013, officials said Friday, when devastating blazes ravaged areas across the state. “It appears that this will probably be the worst one, forecast-wise, in quite some time,” said Mike Morgan, director of the Colorado Division of Fire Prevention and Control. “Abnormally dry weather and a dry winter has left our mountains nearly barren.” While state fire officials hedged that it's too early to have a hard-and-fast prediction for what fire conditions will be this summer, things aren't looking up. Snowpack levels, especially in the southeast and southwest parts of the state, are

author: nanook
title: Greenland's Biggest Fire Is a 'Warning' for Its Future
summary: VIENNA — Last summer, puffs of white appeared in satellite images of western Greenland. These were not patches of snow and ice, but rather plumes of smoke from the island's biggest wildfire on record, burning through miles of thawed peatland. Black carbon particles from smoke plumes can darken Greenland's vast ice sheet, contributing to more heat absorption and more melting. Scientists who studied the wildfire said that nearly a third of the soot landed on Greenland's ice sheet. They warned that much bigger blazes could move through the icy island in the future, and the emissions from these fires could contribute to further melting of the already thinning ice sheet. "I think it's a warning sign

author: captainunderoos
title: OK town threatened by wildfire evacuated
summary: VICI, OKLAHOMA (CNN) - The entire town of Vici - with a 2014 population of 715 - has been evacuated because of a wildfire.  Officials rescued two hunters trapped by the blaze in Dewey County, but a 54-year-old man is still missing.  About 800 homes are threatened in this northwest Oklahoma town, and at least three have been destroyed so far.  Police said they believe the fire has caused more damage in areas they can't access.  Strong winds are fanning the flames. The fire had burned 19,000 acres and was only 20 percent contained late Thursday.

author: nanook
title: Grass fire burns close to Penticton homes
summary: The Penticton Fire Department responded to a grass fire in the West Bench area that broke out around 1:30 p.m. on Wednesday. The bush fire ignited behind a home on Spartan Avenue, before spreading along the gully above the popular KVR trail. Witnesses say the fire was fuelled by strong winds. “It was jumping because the wind really started picking up and then it jumped and all of a sudden you couldn't see anything because the fire was starting to gain more and it just blew up from there,” Roxanne Zeiler, an area resident, said. “It went right into our neighbour's yard across the KVR and up.” RCMP shut down traffic in the area. Fire officials say the blaze is under control and no homes were damaged.

author: third_watch
title: Wyden, Oregon succeed with long overdue wildfire fix: Editorial
summary: For five years, Sen. Ron Wyden has pushed Congress to address how U.S. Forest Service and Bureau of Land Management leaders often must divert money from other programs, including fire prevention and forest management budgets, to cover the increasingly high cost of fighting massive wildfires. Season after season, fire spending consumed an ever-increasing percentage of the federal agencies' relatively flat budgets. Finally, Congress listened and Oregon is likely to benefit. Eventually. The Wildfire Disaster Funding Act was a part of the $1.3 trillion federal spending package passed by federal lawmakers and signed by the president late last month. The act creates an emergency fund of as much as

author: captainunderoos
title: Nicaragua forest fire burns almost 9,000 acres
summary: A forest fire in Nicaragua that has been burning out of control for a week has blackened almost 9,000 acres (3,585 hectares) in a southern nature reserve. The Indio Maiz reserve is on Nicaragua's border with Costa Rica, but the Nicaraguan government has refused Costa Rican offers of aid. The two countries have had long-running disputes over other areas of their border. Costa Rica's firefighting force said Monday that it was told by Nicaraguan officials that soldiers are being sent to fight the blaze so no Costa Rican help was needed. Nicaragua says it has 800 soldiers, five planes and 10 boats fighting the fire.

author: rocky.j.mountain
title: Geoengineering risks losers as well as winners for climate and wildfire risks
summary: While the international community is already aiming to limit global warming to below 2C by reducing greenhouse gas emissions, the more ambitious aim of a 1.5C limit is known to be challenging to reach in this way. An additional method to further limit warming might be to release sulphur dioxide high in the atmosphere, to produce a thin veil of droplets that would reflect some sunlight back to space and help keep the Earth cool. However, the new research suggests that this method of geoengineering could also introduce its own new impacts by shifting global rainfall patterns. The research by scientists at the University of Exeter and the Met Office Hadley Centre, carried out as part of the EU-funded

author: nanook
title: Brush fire forces evacuation of community east of Flagstaff
summary: FLAGSTAFF, AZ (3TV/CBS 5) - A fast-moving brush fire has burned dozens of acres and forced people from a community from their homes east of Flagstaff on Sunday. The Arizona State Forestry said the Copley Fire had burned 86 acres. Officials with the Coconino County Sheriff's Office and Coconino County Emergency Management have evacuated the community of Winona, the agency said. About 75 people were at Summit Fire Station until they were allowed to return home, firefighters said. They were allowed back in their homes around 8:30 p.m. Townsend Winona was closed in both directions. The fire started in a home just before 12:30 p.m. and then turned into a brush fire, said Tiffany Davila with the Arizona

author: captainunderoos
title: Texas, Oklahoma, Kansas facing tornado and wildfire threats
summary: OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) - Emergency officials in Oklahoma, Texas and Kansas are bracing for two types of disasters as spring gets into full swing: The start of what's historically the most active time of year for tornadoes plus wildfire threats brought on by severe drought. April, May and June are the most active months in the U.S. for tornadoes. At the same time, the three states on the southern end of Tornado Alley are experiencing extreme and exceptional drought that could fuel wildfires. Tornado Alley extends from northern Texas and covers much of Oklahoma, Kansas, Nebraska and South Dakota, plus slivers of New Mexico and Colorado, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's

author: rocky.j.mountain
title: Wildland fire near U.S. 50 and I-25 bypass
summary: Pueblo emergency responders from multiple agencies battled a wildfire near Fountain Creek just south of Highway 50 near the Interstate 25 bypass Wednesday afternoon. The fire was reported to have burned seven acres and was 100 percent contained as of 9 p.m. Wednesday. No injuries were reported, despite the fact the fire took place in an area known to feature numerous homeless camps. Pueblo Fire Department spokesman Erik Duran said the fire is believed to have originated at an established homeless camp in the area, but its direct cause is currently unknown. The area had coincidentally been visited by emergency responders from multiple agencies earlier in the day during a homeless outreach program.

author: nanook
title: California fights wildfires aggressively — but prevention takes a back seat
summary: Dave Kinateder has a keen eye for trees. “It's a ticking time bomb,” he said, gazing across the dense, green carpet of trees near Quincy, a small community high in the northern Sierra Nevada. Last year's wildfires, the worst in modern California history, have put a microscope on the forests that cover a third of the state–in particular, on managing these wooded lands in ways that would reduce the frequency and intensity of such blazes. California is grappling with the counterintuitive dilemma of too many trees, packed too closely together, robbed of the space they need to thrive—and with how to clear out more than 100 million dead trees, felled by drought or insects, that provide tinder for the next infernos.

author: third_watch
title: Cause of Darien brush fires along Frontage Road undetermined
summary: The cause of four small brush fires Sunday along Frontage Road near Lemont Road in Darien has not been determined. Darien- Woodridge Fire Protection District Deputy Chief Darren Leno said Tuesday an investigation was done and the cause could not be determined. The Darien Police Department asked via Twitter on Sunday for anyone who has information about what may have started the fires to contact the Police Department or the fire protection district. A passer-by reported the fires at about 1:55 p.m. April 1, Leno said. There were four separate brush fires on the north side of North Frontage Road just east of Lemont Road, Leno said. Firefighters extinguished the fires. It appeared just dry vegetation

author: captainunderoos
title: Brush Fire Prompts Evacuation in Port St. Lucie

author: DeltaBravo
title: Pacific Northwest firefighters expect another busy season
summary: YAKIMA — Wildland firefighters expect the Pacific Northwest will see another busy fire season this year with land around Yakima especially vulnerable. “If I were to pick one place that might experience above-average fire danger, it's the Yakima Valley and the eastern slopes” of the Cascade Mountains, said Josh Clark, a meteorologist with the state Department of Natural Resources. Less rain in the winter, above-average temperatures and less mountain snow mean fires could start earlier and burn longer than a typical season, Clark said. Clark spoke at a conference of wildland firefighters from Alaska, Washington and Oregon held at the Yakima Convention Center. Washington has seen a dramatic increase

author: third_watch
title: Florida's wildfire season is here: What you need to know
summary: The wildfire danger is currently either moderate or high in every Tampa Bay area county. Tampa Bay residents need to know they are at risk if they live near a wooded or conservation area or even swamp land. It is currently Florida's wildfire season, and it is expected to be bad this year, partly because of all the debris left behind by Hurricane Irma. Forestry officials want everyone to take this seriously so they can better prepare their homes in the event of a wildfire. "This is great. They have rocks, cement, they have a chain link fence. All those things help us help them fight that fire," said Florida Foresty spokesperson Judy Tear. Tear showed 10News some simple things one family did, that

author: ipostwhaticareabout
title: I-95 near New Smyrna Beach reopens after brush fire
summary: Both directions of I-95 near New Smyrna Beach reopened Thursday morning after a brush fire had them closed since Wednesday, the Florida Highway Patrol said. The interstate was shut down between State Road 44 and Dunlawton until about 9:30 a.m., troopers said. Troopers said drivers still need to use caution, as there is some lingering smoke. Troopers said they will continue to monitor I-95 throughout the day. idantonio@orlandosentinel.com or 407-420-5700

author: ipostwhaticareabout
title: Hot air balloon crashes and catches fire but no one injured
summary: PHOENIX (AP) — Authorities say a hot air balloon carrying 13 people crashed and caught fire Wednesday morning in the desert outside Phoenix, igniting a small brush fire but causing no injuries.

author: rocky.j.mountain
title: Brush fire closes portion of Alligator Alley in Florida
summary: A portion of Interstate 75 known as Alligator Alley is closed due to heavy smoke from a brush fire. Collier County Sheriff's officials said in a Facebook posting that the interstate is closed from the toll booth in Collier County on Florida's Gulf Coast to the toll booth in Broward County. The interstate is the major east-west highway that crosses the state on its southern end. Officials suggest State Road 80 to U.S. 27 as an alternative route for motorists trying to head east. Firefighters have been battling brush fires in southwest Florida since last week.

author: captainunderoos
title: Alberta government commits $34.5M towards agricultural societies
summary: The Alberta government has announced additional funding for agricultural societies and rural programs. The government said Alberta's 283 agricultural societies will be receiving $11.5 million annually for the next three years to help plan ahead and create budgets for the facilities, events and education they provide in their communities. “I'm pleased that we can continue to support the vital work that agricultural societies do in our province to encourage growth in the agriculture industry and rural Alberta, and educate the next generation of farmers and ranchers,” Agriculture and Forestry Minister Oneil Carlier said. “Ag societies are our partners in delivering many community-centred initiatives,
